Package com.accele.gage.gfx

Class Window

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.accele.gage.gfx.Window
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cleanable
    public class Window
extends java.lang.Object
implements Cleanable
    The Window class acts as an intermediary between the engine and the underlying windowing system and is used to display content to the screen.

    GAGE uses the programmable pipeline version of the LWJGL (and by extension OpenGL) API to display graphics. This means that the Display class, which was available in LWJGL up until version 3, is no longer available, so GLFW is now used instead.

    GLFW provides a set of available window hints to specify upon window creation to modify the settings of the context. In addition to using windowed mode by default, GAGE uses the following default window hints: 

     glfwWindowHint(GLFW_SAMPLES, 4);
 glfwWindowHint(GLFW_CONTEXT_VERSION_MAJOR, 3);
 glfwWindowHint(GLFW_CONTEXT_VERSION_MINOR, 3);
 glfwWindowHint(GLFW_OPENGL_FORWARD_COMPAT, GLFW_TRUE);
 glfwWindowHint(GLFW_OPENGL_PROFILE, GLFW_OPENGL_CORE_PROFILE);

    To specify custom window hints, call the setCustomWindowHints(int[]) method prior to initializing the engine.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    Version:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    William Garland

    • Constructor Detail

      • Window

        public Window​(int width,
              int height,
              java.lang.String title,
              int[] windowHints)
        Initializes the Window using the specified width, height, title, and windowHints.

        This constructor is not intended to be called by the user; Window creation is handled by the engine. The width, height, and title of the Window is specified using the init(int, int, String) method. For window hints, GAGE has a list of preset hints (see the Window class for a complete list); to specify custom window hints, call the setCustomWindowHints(int[]) method prior to initializing the engine.

        Parameters:
        width - the width of the window
        height - the height of the window
        title - the title of the window
        windowHints - the window hints to use when initializing the window
        See Also:
        Window

    • Method Detail

      • isFullscreen

        public boolean isFullscreen()
        Returns the full screen status of the window.

        By default, GAGE initializes its window using windowed mode. To set the window to full screen, use setFullscreen(boolean).

        Returns:
        the full screen status of the window

      • setFullscreen

        public void setFullscreen​(boolean fullscreen)
        Sets the full screen status of the window.
        Parameters:
        fullscreen - whether the window should be full screen

      • getMonitors

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.Long,​java.lang.String> getMonitors()
        Returns a Map of all currently connected monitors in which the key is the pointer to the monitor and the value is the name of the monitor.
        Returns:
        a Map of all currently connected monitors

      • getVideoModes

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.Long,​java.util.List<org.lwjgl.glfw.GLFWVidMode>> getVideoModes()
        Returns a Map of all supported video modes per monitor in which the key is the pointer to the monitor and the value is the List of all supported video modes for that specific monitor.
        Returns:
        a Map of all supported video modes per monitor

      • show

        public void show()
        Shows the window if it was previously hidden. GAGE automatically shows the window upon calling the start() method.

      • hide

        public void hide()
        Hides the window if it is currently being shown. GAGE automatically shows the window upon calling the start() method.

      • onCycleBegin

        public void onCycleBegin()
        Called at the beginning of every game loop cycle to clear the screen. This method is for internal use only and should not be called directly by the user.

      • onCycleEnd

        public void onCycleEnd()
        Called at the end of every game loop cycle to swap window buffers and poll input events. This method is for internal use only and should not be called directly by the user.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the window and stops the engine. This method has the same effect as calling stop().

      • isClosed

        public boolean isClosed()
        Returns the closed status of the window. This method will return true if either the window is closed manually using the setClosed(boolean) method or if the window is closed due to an external process (i.e. pressing the close button).
        Returns:
        the closed status of the window

      • clean

        public void clean()
        Description copied from interface: Cleanable
        Allows the implementer to perform any necessary cleanup tasks. For most engine-specific resources, this method should not be called manually as it is usually always called after stop() has been called.
        Specified by:
        clean in interface Cleanable
